intro: Alnus viridis f. macrophylla, commonly known as the large-leaf alder, is a variant of the alder tree native to North America. It is characterized by its broad, ovate leaves that are typically 5–10 cm in length, giving it a distinctive appearance. The plant is a deciduous tree or shrub that thrives in moist, well-drained soils, often found near streams or in wetlands. It produces small, yellowish catkins in early spring, which are essential for its reproductive cycle. The leaves and seeds of this plant are used by various wildlife species, contributing to its ecological importance.
